summary: This is a formal notification letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida to an identified victim of Jeffrey Epstein, informing them of his 2008 guilty plea and sentence in Florida state court, and outlining the process for civil claims, including the appointment of a special attorney representative paid for by Epstein.

persons.name: Robert Josefsberg
persons.role: Attorney representative for victims selected by Special Master
persons.context: Selected by an independent Special Master to represent the victims, including the recipient, in civil actions against Epstein. His services are to be provided at no cost to the victims as Epstein is obligated to pay.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signed the notification letter to the victim.

connections.description: Josefsberg is appointed as the potential attorney representative for the victim in civil actions against Epstein.
Josefsberg is selected to represent victims in civil actions against the defendant (Epstein), whom he is obligated to pay Josefsberg's fees.

events.title: Epstein's Guilty Plea and Sentencing
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered a guilty plea to violations of Florida statutes and was sentenced to 12 months' imprisonment, followed by 6 months' imprisonment, then 12 months of Community Control.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein pleaded guilty and was sentenced on June 30, 2008, in a Florida state case.
The U.S. Attorney's Office agreed to defer federal prosecution in favor of the state plea and sentence, subject to conditions.
A key condition was the appointment of an independent Special Master who selected attorney Robert Josefsberg to represent victims in civil actions, with Epstein obligated to pay his fees.
The letter outlines a specific civil claim process under 18 U.S.C. ยง 2255 where Epstein agreed not to contest jurisdiction, liability, or damages up to an agreed amount.
The letter references existing litigation between the U.S. and two other victims (Jane Does 1 and 2) regarding the disclosure of the full non-prosecution agreement.
